{{Buddhist term |title=vijñāna |pi=विञ्ञाण (viññāṇa) |sa=विज्ञान (vijñāna) |zh=識(T) / 识(S) |zh-Latn=shí |ko=식/識 (shik) |km=វិញ្ញាណ
(Vinh Nhean) |ja=識 (shiki) |vi=識 (thức) |th=วิญญาณ |bo=རྣམ་པར་ཤེས་པ་ |en=consciousness,
mind, life force,
discernment |my=ဝိညာဉ် |my-Latn={{IPA|wḭ ɲɪ̀ɴ}} |si=[[:si:විඥානය|විඥ්ඥාන]] }} '''''Vijñāna''''' ([[Sanskrit]]) or '''''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''''' ([[Pali|Pāli]])As is standard in WP articles, the Pali term ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' will be used when discussing the [[Pali literature]], and the Sanskrit word ''vijñāna'' will be used when referring to either texts chronologically subsequent to the Pali canon or when discussing the topic broadly, in terms of ''both'' Pali and non-Pali texts. is translated as "[[consciousness]]," "life force," "mind,"See, for instance, Rhys Davids & Stede (1921-25), p. 618, entry for "Viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a," retrieved on 2007-06-17 from the University of Chicago's "Digital Dictionaries of South Asia". [https://archive.is/20121211114628/http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.3:1:1470.pali University of Chicago] or "discernment."See, for instance, [http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/apte/frontmatter/apte.pdf Apte (1957-59)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328232611/http://dsal.uchicago.edu/dictionaries/apte/frontmatter/apte.pdf |date=March 28, 2016 }}, p. 1434, entry for "vijñānam," retrieved from "U. Chicago" at http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.5:1:2152.apte{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ; and, [http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/monier/index.html Monier-Williams (rev. 2008)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202002/http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/monier/index.html |date=March 3, 2016 }}, p. 961, entry for "Vi-jñāna," retrieved from "U. Cologne" at {{cite web |url=http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/monier/serveimg.pl?file%3D%2Fscans%2FMWScan%2FMWScanjpg%2Fmw0961-vijRmbhin.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160514071912/http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/monier/serveimg.pl?file=%2Fscans%2FMWScan%2FMWScanjpg%2Fmw0961-vijRmbhin.jpg |archivedate=2016-05-14 |df= }} . In the [[Pāli Canon]]'s ''[[Sutta Pitaka]]'''s first four [[nikāya]]s, ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' is one of three overlapping Pali terms used to refer to the mind, the others being ''[[Manas (early Buddhism)|manas]]'' and ''[[citta]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/vijnana-449563|title=What is Vijnana in Buddhism?|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2017-05-07}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.srichinmoylibrary.com/ag-70|title=Question: What is the difference between jnana and vijnana? {{!}} Sri Chinmoy Library|website=www.srichinmoylibrary.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/alaya-vijnana-the-storehouse-consciousness-449659|title=Alaya-vijnana: The Storehouse Consciousness, Source of All Experience|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2017-05-07}} Each is used in the generic and non-technical sense of "mind" in general, but the three are sometimes used in sequence to refer to one's mental processes as a whole.Sue Hamilton, ''Identity and Experience.'' LUZAC Oriental, 1996, pages 105-106. Their primary uses are, however, distinct.Bodhi, Bhikkhu (trans.) (2000b). ''The Connected Discourses of the Buddha: A Translation of the Samyutta Nikaya''. (Part IV is "The Book of the Six Sense Bases (Salayatanavagga)".) Boston: Wisdom Publications. {{ISBN|0-86171-331-1}}., pp. 769-70, ''n''. 154. For more information, see the section, "[[Vijñāna#Overlapping Pali terms for mind|Overlapping Pali terms for mind]]," below. ==Buddhism== This section considers the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] concept primarily in terms of [[Early Buddhism]]'s [[Pali literature]] as well as in the literature of other [[Schools of Buddhism|Buddhist schools]]. ===Pali literature=== Throughout Pali literature, ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' can be found as one of a handful of synonyms for the mental force that animates the otherwise inert material body.Rhys Davids & Stede (1921-25), entry for "Viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a," states: :"In what may be a very old Sutta [[Samyutta Nikaya|S]] ii.95 [viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a] is given as a synonym of citta (q. v.) and mano (q. v.), in opposition to kāya used to mean body. This simpler unecclesiastical, unscholastic popular meaning is met with in other [[Sūtra|sutta]]s. E. g. the body (kāya) is when animated called '''sa-viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}aka''' [with consciousness]...." Bodhi (2000b), pp. 769-70, n. 154, also mentions this generalized use of ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' in the [[Abhidhamma Pitaka]] and [[atthakatha|commentaries]] (cf. "[[#Overlapping_Pali_terms_for_mind|Overlapping Pali terms for mind]]" section below). In a number of Pali texts though, the term has a more nuanced and context-specific (or "technical") meaning. In particular, in the [[Pali Canon]]'s "Discourse Basket" (''[[Suttapitaka]]''), ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' (generally translated as "consciousness") is discussed in at least three related but different contexts:
:(1) as a derivative of the sense bases (''[[āyatana]]''), part of the experientially exhaustive "All" (''sabba''); :(2) as one of the five aggregates (''[[Skandha|khandha]]'') of clinging (''[[upadana]]'') at the root of suffering (''[[dukkha]]''); and, :(3) as one of the twelve causes (''[[Twelve Nidanas|nidana]]'') of "Dependent Origination" (''[[Pratitya-samutpada|paticcasamuppāda]]'') which provides a template for Buddhist notions of [[Karma in Buddhism|kamma]], [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]] and release. In the Pali Canon's [[Abhidhamma]] and in post-canonical [[Atthakatha|Pali commentaries]], consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is further analyzed into 89 different states which are categorized in accordance with their kammic results. {{Chachakka|figno=1}} {{PancaKhandha|figno=2}} ====Sense-base derivative==== In Buddhism, the [[Sadayatana|six sense bases]] (Pali: ''{{IAST|saḷāyatana}}''; Skt.: ''{{IAST|ṣaḍāyatana}}'') refer to the five physical sense organs (cf. [[receptive field]]) (belonging to the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body), the mind (referred to as the sixth sense base) and their associated objects (visual forms, sounds, odors, flavors, touch and mental objects). Based on the six sense bases, a number of mental factors arise including six "types" or "classes" of consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a-kāyā''). More specifically, according to this analysis, the six types of consciousness are eye-consciousness (that is, consciousness based on the eye), ear-consciousness, nose-consciousness, tongue-consciousness, body-consciousness and mind-consciousness.See, for instance, [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 148 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.148.than.html (Thanissaro, 1998).] In this framework, the Pali word translated as "consciousness" is ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' and the word translated as "mind" is ''mano''. Thus, the faculty of awareness of the mind (the base of, e.g., abstractions sythesized from physical sensory experience) is referred to as ''mano-viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' ("mind-consciousness"). In this context, for instance, when an ear's receptive field (the [[proximal stimulus]], more commonly known by Buddhists as a sense base, or sense organ) and sound (the [[distal stimulus]], or sense object) are present, the associated (ear-related consciousness) arises. The arising of these three elements (''dhātu'') – e.g. ear, sound and ear-consciousness – lead to the [[percept]], known as "[[phassa|contact]]" and in turn causes a pleasant, unpleasant or neutral "[[vedana|feeling]]" to arise. It is from such feeling that "[[tanha|craving]]" arises. (See Fig. 1.) In a discourse entitled, "The All" (''Sabba Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 35.23), the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] states that there is no "all" outside of the six pairs of sense bases (that is, six internal and six external sense bases).Bodhi (2000b), p. 1140; and, [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.023.than.html Thanissaro (2001c).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303215645/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.023.than.html |date=March 3, 2016 }} According to Bodhi (2000b), p. 1399, ''n''. 7, the Pali commentary regarding the ''Sabba Sutta'' states: "...[I]f one passes over the twelve sense bases, one cannot point out any real phenomenon." Also see [https://archive.is/20120707171513/http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.3:1:3261.pali Rhys Davids & Stede (1921-25), p. 680, "Sabba" entry] where ''{{IAST|sabbaŋ}}'' is defined as "the (whole) world of sense-experience." References to the "All" (''sabba'') can be found in a number of subsequent discourses including [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 35.24, 35.25, 35.26, 35.27 and 35.29. The "To Be Abandoned Discourse" (''Pahanaya Sutta'', SN 35.24) further expands the All to include first five aforementioned sextets (internal sense bases, external sense bases, consciousness, contact and feeling).Bodhi (2000b), p. 1140; and, [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.024.than.html Thanissaro (2001b).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508030327/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.024.than.html |date=May 8, 2016 }} These five sextets are implicitly referenced as the bases for clinging (''[[upādāna]]'') and [[fetters (Buddhism)|fetters]] in other discourses such as "Advice to Anāthapi{{IAST|ṇḍ}}ika Discourse" (''Anāthapi{{IAST|ṇḍ}}ikavāda Sutta'' [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 143; Ñā{{IAST|ṇ}}amoli & Bodhi, 2001, pp. 1109-13) and the "Great Discourse on the Sixfold Base" (''Mahāsa{{IAST|ḷ}}āyatanika Sutta'' [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 149; Ñā{{IAST|ṇ}}amoli & Bodhi, 2001, pp. 1137-39).In the "Six Sextets" discourse (''Chachakka Sutta'', [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 148), a further expansion can be seen where the "six sextets" (''cha-chakka'') include the five aforementioned sextets plus feeling-dependent craving (''[[taṇhā|ta{{IAST|ṇ}}hā]]''). (For MN 148, see Ñā{{IAST|ṇ}}amoli & Bodhi (2001), pp. 1129-36; and, [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.148.than.html Thanissaro (1998).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421005716/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.148.than.html |date=April 21, 2016 }}) In the famed "[[Fire Sermon]]" (''Ādittapariyāya Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 35.28) the Buddha declares that "the All is aflame" with passion, aversion, delusion and suffering (''[[dukkha]]''); to obtain release from this suffering, one should become disenchanted with the All.[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.028.than.html Thanissaro (1993).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421022933/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn35/sn35.028.than.html |date=April 21, 2016 }} Hence, in this context, ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' includes the following characteristics: * ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' arises as a result of the material sense bases (''[[āyatana]]'')This, for instance, can be juxtaposed with an [[Idealism|Idealist]] epistemology where the material world arises from consciousness (Bodhi, 2006). * there are six types of consciousness, each unique to one of the internal sense organs * consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is separate (and arises) from mind (''mano'') * here, consciousness cognizes or is aware of its specific sense base (including the mind and mind objects) * ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' is a prerequisite for the arising of craving (''ta{{IAST|ṇ}}hā'') * hence, for the vanquishing of suffering (''dukkha''), one should neither identify with nor attach to ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' ====The aggregates==== In Buddhism, consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is one of the five classically defined experiential "[[skandha|aggregates]]" (Pali: ''khandha''; Skt.: ''skandha''). As illustrated (Fig. 2), the four other aggregates are material "form" (''[[rupa (Buddhism)|rupa]]''), "feeling" or "sensation" (''[[vedana]]''), "perception" (''[[saṃjñā|sanna]]''), and "volitional formations" or "fabrications" (''[[sankhara]]''). In [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 22.79, the Buddha distinguishes consciousness in the following manner: :"And why do you call it 'consciousness'? Because it cognizes, thus it is called consciousness. What does it cognize? It cognizes what is sour, bitter, pungent, sweet, alkaline, non-alkaline, salty, & unsalty. Because it cognizes, it is called consciousness."''Khajjaniya Sutta'' ("Chewed Up," [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 22.29) [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn22/sn22.079.than.html (Thanissaro, 2001a).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230225/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn22/sn22.079.than.html |date=March 3, 2016 }} This type of awareness appears to be more refined and introspective than that associated with the aggregate of perception (''saññā'') which the Buddha describes in the same discourse as follows: :"And why do you call it 'perception'? Because it perceives, thus it is called 'perception.' What does it perceive? It perceives blue, it perceives yellow, it perceives red, it perceives white. Because it perceives, it is called perception."''Khajjaniya Sutta'' ("Chewed Up," [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 22.29) [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn22/sn22.079.than.html (Thanissaro, 2001a).] Regarding SN 22.79's typifying perception (saññā) through visual colors and consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') through assorted tastes, Bodhi (2000b, p. 1072, n. 114) mentions that the Samyutta Nikaya's subcommentary states that perception grasps appearances and shapes while consciousness "can grasp particular distinctions in an object even when there is no appearance and shape." Similarly, in the traditionally venerated 5th-century CE commentary, the [[Visuddhimagga]], there is an extended analogy about a child, an adult villager and an expert "money-changer" seeing a heap of coins; the child's experience is likened to perception, the villager's experience to consciousness, and the money-changer's experience to true understanding (''[[Wisdom in Buddhism|paňňā]]'').[[Buddhaghosa]] (1999), pp. 435-6) Thus, in this context, "consciousness" denotes more than the irreducible subjective experience of sense data suggested in the discourses of "the All" (see prior section); it additionally entails a depth of awareness reflecting a degree of memory and recognition. All of the aggregates are to be seen as [[anatta|empty of self-nature]]; that is, they arise dependent on causes (''hetu'') and conditions (''paticca''). In this scheme, the cause for the arising of consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is the arising of one of the other aggregates (physical or mental); and the arising of consciousness in turn gives rise to one or more of the mental (''nāma'') aggregates. In this way, the chain of causation identified in the aggregate (''khandha'') model overlaps the chain of conditioning in the Dependent Origination (''[[Pratitya-samutpada|paticcasamuppāda]]'') model.This overlap is particularly pronounced in the ''Mahanidana Sutta'' ([[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 15) where consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is a condition of name-and-body (''nāmarūpa'') and ''vice versa'' (see, e.g., Thanissaro, 1997a). ====Dependent origination==== Consciousness (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') is the third of the traditionally enumerated [[Twelve Nidanas|Twelve Causes]] (''nidāna'') of [[Pratitya-samutpada|Dependent Origination]] (Pali: ''{{IAST|paṭiccasamuppāda}}''; Skt.: ''pratītyasamutpāda'').Not all canonical texts identify twelve causes in Dependent Origination's causal chain. For instance, the ''Mahanidana Sutta'' ([[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 15) [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/dn/dn.15.0.than.html (Thanissaro, 1997a)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421133205/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/dn/dn.15.0.than.html |date=April 21, 2016 }} identifies only nine causes (omitting the six sense bases, formations and ignorance) and the initial text of the ''Nalakalapiyo Sutta'' ([[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.67) [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.067.than.html (Thanissaro, 2000)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160503051913/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.067.than.html |date=May 3, 2016 }} twice identifies ten causes (omitting formations and ignorance) although its final enumeration includes the twelve traditional factors. Within the context of Dependent Origination, different canonical discourses represent different aspects of consciousness.For instance, similar to the sensory-specific description of consciousness found in discussing "the All" (above), the "Analysis of Dependent Origination Discourse" (''Paticcasamuppada-vibhanga Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.2) describes ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' ("consciousness") in the following manner: :"And what is ''consciousness''? These six are classes of consciousness: eye-consciousness, ear-consciousness, nose-consciousness, tongue-consciousness, body-consciousness, intellect-consciousness. This is called consciousness." [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.002.than.html (Thanissaro, 1997b)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504215121/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.002.than.html |date=May 4, 2016 }} The following aspects are traditionally highlighted: :* consciousness is conditioned by mental fabrications (''{{IAST|[[sankhara|saṅkhāra]]}}''); :* consciousness and the mind-body (''[[namarupa|nāmarūpa]]'') are interdependent; and, :* consciousness acts as a "life force" by which there is a continuity across rebirths. =====Mental-fabrication conditioning and kamma===== Numerous discourses state: :"From fabrications [''{{IAST|[[sankhara|saṅkhāra]]}}''] as a requisite condition comes consciousness [''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'']."For instance, see the ''Paticcasamuppada-vibhanga Sutta'' ([[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.2) [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.002.than.html (Thanissaro, 1997b).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504215121/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.002.than.html |date=May 4, 2016 }} Square-bracketed Pali terms were added. Also see various other discourses in the [[Samyutta Nikaya]]'s chapter 12. In three discourses in the [[Samyutta Nikaya]], the Buddha highlights three particular manifestations of ''{{IAST|saṅkhāra}}'' as particularly creating a "basis for the maintenance of consciousness" (''{{IAST|ārammaṇaṃ ... viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā}}'') that could lead to future existence,''punabbhavābhinibbatti'' ("for again becoming reborn"), mentioned in "Volition (1) Discourse" (Bodhi, 2000b, p. 576) to the perpetuation of bodily and mental processes,''nāmarūpassa avakkanti'' ("for entry of name-and-form"), mentioned in "Volition (2) Discourse" (Bodhi, 2000b, pp. 576-77). and to craving''Nati'' (literally, "bending" or "inclination"), which the Samyutta Nikaya commentary states is synonymous with "[[tanha|craving]], called 'inclination' in the sense of inclining ... towards pleasant forms, etc.," mentioned in "Volition (3) Discourse" and its end notes (Bodhi, 2000b, pp. 577, 761 ''n''. 116). and its resultant suffering. As stated in the common text below (in English and Pali), these three manifestations are intending, planning and enactments of latent tendencies ("obsessing")''ca ceteti ca pakappeti ca anuseti'': Rhys Davids & Stede (1921–25) translate this as "to intend, to start to perform, to carry out" (pp. 268–69, entry for "Cinteti & ceteti" (retrieved 2007-11-21 at http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.1:1:1497.pali){{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}; Bodhi (2000b) translates this as "intends ... plans ... has a tendency towards" (pp. 576–77); and, [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.038.than.html Thanissaro (1995)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504215333/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.038.than.html |date=May 4, 2016 }} translates it as "intends ... arranges ... obsesses about." Thanissaro (1995), ''n''. 1, further elaborates: :"The seven obsessions are: the obsession of sensual passion, the obsession of resistance, the obsession of views, the obsession of uncertainty, the obsession of conceit, the obsession of passion for becoming, and the obsession of ignorance. See [[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 7.12." {{Nidanas|float=right}} {| style="margin:auto" |- style="vertical-align:top" | style="padding-right:2em" | ... [W]hat one intends, and what one plans, and whatever one has a tendency towards:
this becomes a basis for the maintenance of consciousness.
When there is a basis there is a support for the establishing of consciousness."Volition (1) Discourse," "Volition (2) Discourse" and "Volition (3) Discourse" (Bodhi, 2000b, pp. 576-77). | Yañca ... ceteti, yañca pakappeti, yañca anuseti,
{{IAST|ārammaṇametaṃ hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.}}
{{IAST|Ārammaṇe sati patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa hoti.}}''{{IAST|Cetanāsuttaṃ}}'', ''{{IAST|Dutiya-cetanāsuttaṃ}}'' and ''{{IAST|Tatiya-cetanāsuttaṃ}}'' (La Trobe University, n.d., [[Samyutta Nikaya]], book 2, BJT pp. 102, 104. [http://www.chaf.lib.latrobe.edu.au/dcd/tipitika.php?title=&record=4293 La Trobe University, Australia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909110338/http://www.chaf.lib.latrobe.edu.au/dcd/tipitika.php?title=&record=4293 |date=2007-09-09 }} retrieved 2007-11-21 |} Thus, for instance, in the "Intention Discourse" (''Cetanā Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.38), the Buddha more fully elaborates: :[[Bhikkhu]]s, what one intends, and what one plans, and whatever one has a tendency towards: this becomes a basis for the maintenance of consciousness. When there is a basis there is a support for the establishing of consciousness. When consciousness is established and has come to growth, there is the production of future renewed [[bhava|existence]]. When there is the production of future renewed existence, future [[jati (Buddhism)|birth]], [[jaramarana|aging-and-death]], sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of [[dukkha|suffering]].Bodhi (2000b), p. 576. Also see [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.038.than.html Thanissaro (1995).] The language of the post-canonical Samyutta Nikaya [[atthakatha|commentary]] and [[Subcommentaries, Theravada|subcommentary]] further affirm that this text is discussing the means by which "kammic consciousness" "yield[s] fruit in one's mental continuum."Bodhi (2000b), pp. 757-9 ''n''. 112. In other words, certain intentional or obsessive acts on one's part inherently establish in present consciousness a basis for future consciousness's existence; in this way, the future existence is conditioned by certain aspects of the initial intention, including its wholesome and unwholesome qualities. Conversely, in the "Attached Discourse" (''Upaya Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 22.53), it states that if passion for the five [[skandha|aggregates]] (forms and mental processes) are abandoned then: :"... owing to the abandonment of passion, the support is cut off, and there is no base for consciousness. Consciousness, thus unestablished, not proliferating, not performing any function, is released. Owing to its release, it is steady. Owing to its steadiness, it is contented. Owing to its contentment, it is not agitated. Not agitated, he (the monk) is totally unbound right within. He discerns that 'Birth is ended, the holy life fulfilled, the task done. There is nothing further for this world.'"[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn22/sn22.053.than.html Thanissaro (1997c).] Parenthetical phrase "(the monk)" is in the original translation. Also see Bodhi (2000b), pp. 890-91. Note that "unbound" is Thanissaro's translation of "nibbāna" (Pali; Sanskrit: [[nirvana]]); thus, Bodhi (2000b), p. 891, provides the alternate translation of "Being unagitated, he personally attains Nibbāna." =====Mind-body interdependency===== Numerous discourses state: :"From consciousness [''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''] as a requisite condition comes name-form [''[[namarupa|nāmarūpa]]'']." In addition, a few discourses state that, simultaneously, the converse is true: :"Consciousness comes from name-form as its requisite condition."See, for instance, [[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 15 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/dn/dn.15.0.than.html (Thanissaro, 1997a)], and [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.67 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.067.than.html (Thanissaro, 2000)].As indicated in the immediately preceding section, "fabrications" (also known as "formations" or "mental formations" or "volitional formations") — as opposed to "name-form" — are more often identified as the requisite conditions for consciousness. These two different statements are not however contradictory insomuch that, as indicated by the [[skandha|Five Aggregates]] model, name-form includes mental fabrications (see the "Five Aggregates" diagram above). In the "Sheaves of Reeds Discourse" (''Nalakalapiyo Sutta'', [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 12.67), Ven. [[Sariputta]] uses this famous analogy to explain the interdependency of consciousness and name-form: :"It is as if two sheaves of reeds were to stand leaning against one another. In the same way, from name-form as a requisite condition comes consciousness, from consciousness as a requisite condition comes name-form.... :"If one were to pull away one of those sheaves of reeds, the other would fall; if one were to pull away the other, the first one would fall. In the same way, from the cessation of name-form comes the cessation of consciousness, from the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of name-form...."[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn12/sn12.067.than.html Thanissaro (2000).] ====="Life force" aspect and rebirth===== As described above in the discussion of mental fabrications' conditioning of consciousness, past intentional actions establish a [[Karma in Buddhism|kammic]] seed within consciousness that expresses itself in the future. Through consciousness's "life force" aspect, these future expressions are not only within a single lifespan but propel kammic impulses (''kammavega'') across [[samsara|samsaric]] [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]]s. In the "Serene Faith Discourse" (''Sampasadaniya Sutta'', [[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 28), Ven. [[Sariputta]] references not a singular conscious entity but a "stream of consciousness" (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a-sota'') that spans multiple lives: :"... [U]nsurpassed is the Blessed Lord's way of teaching [[Dhamma]] in regard to the attainment of vision.... Here, some ascetic or Brahmin, by means of ardour, endeavour, application, vigilence and due attention, reaches such a level of concentration that he ... comes to know the unbroken stream of human consciousness as established both in this world and in the next...."Walshe (1995), pp. 419-20, para. 7. In an end note on p. 606, ''n''. 865, Walshe states that ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a-sota'' is "a rare expression which seems to equate with ''[[bhavanga]]'', the (mainly) [[atthakatha|commentarial]] term for the 'life-continuum' (Ñā{{IAST|ṇ}}amoli)." The error of attributing to the Buddha a teaching that consciousness across life spans is a ''singular'' entity is the mistake made by a bhikkhu named Sati who is publicly upbraided for this misconstrual by the Buddha in the "Greater Discourse on the Destruction of Craving" (''Mahatanhasankhya Sutta'', [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 38; trans. Ñā{{IAST|ṇ}}amoli & Bodhi, 2001, pp. 349-61). Note that the phrase "steam of consciousness" here refers to successive, interdependent conscious ''states'' as opposed to Western psychology's use of "[[Stream of consciousness (psychology)|stream of consciousness]]" to refer to successive, interdependent conscious ''thoughts''. The "Great Causes Discourse" (''Mahanidana Sutta'', [[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 15), in a dialogue between the Buddha and the Ven. [[Ananda]], describes "consciousness" (''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'') in a way that underlines its "life force" aspect: :"'From consciousness as a requisite condition comes name-and-form.' Thus it has been said. And this is the way to understand how from consciousness as a requisite condition comes name-and-form. If consciousness were not to descend into the mother's womb, would name-and-form take shape in the womb?" :"No, lord." :"If, after descending into the womb, consciousness were to depart, would name-and-form be produced for this world?" :"No, lord." :"If the consciousness of the young boy or girl were to be cut off, would name-and-form ripen, grow, and reach maturity?" :"No, lord." :"Thus this is a cause, this is a reason, this is an origination, this is a requisite condition for name-and-form, i.e., consciousness."[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/dn/dn.15.0.than.html Thanissaro (1997a).] Discourses such as this {{According to whom|appear|date=December 2013}} to describe a consciousness that is an animating phenomenon capable of spanning lives thus giving rise to rebirth. An [[Anguttara Nikaya]] discourse provides a memorable metaphor to describe the interplay of kamma, consciousness, craving and rebirth: :[Ananda:] "One speaks, Lord, of 'becoming, becoming'. How does becoming tak[e] place?" :[Buddha:] "... Ānanda, kamma is the field, consciousness the seed and craving the moisture for consciousness of beings hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving to become established in [one of the [[Tiloka|"three worlds"]]]. Thus, there is re-becoming in the future."[[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 3.76 (Nyanaponika & Bodhi, 1999, p. 69.) ====Abhidhammic analysis==== The [[Patthana]], part of the [[Theravada|Theravadin]] [[Abhidharma]], analyzes the different states of consciousness and their functions. The Theravāda school method is to study every state of consciousness. Using this method, some states of consciousness are identified as positive, some negative and some neutral. This analysis is based on the principle of [[karma]], the main point in understanding the different consciousness. All together according to the Abhidhamma, there are 89 kinds of consciousness, 54 are of the "sense sphere" (related to the five physical senses as well as craving for sensual pleasure), 15 of the "fine-material sphere" (related to the meditative absorptions based on material objects), 12 of the "immaterial sphere" (related to the immaterial meditative absorptions), and eight are supramundane (related to the realization of [[Nirvana|Nibbāna]]).Bodhi (2000a), pp. 28-31. More specifically, a ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' is a single moment of conceptual consciousness and normal mental activity is considered to consist of a continual succession of ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''s. ''Viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'' has two components: the awareness itself, and the object of that awareness (which might be a perception, a feeling etc.). Thus, in this way, these ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''s are not considered as ultimate (underived) phenomena as they are based on mental factors (''cetasika''). For example, [[Dhyāna in Buddhism|jhānic]] (meditative) states are described as based on the five ultimate mental factors of applied thought (''[[vitakka]]''), sustained thought (''[[vicara]]''), rapture (''[[Pīti|piti]]''), serenity (''[[sukha]]'') and one-pointedness (''[[ekaggata|ekaggatā]]'').{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} ====Overlapping Pali terms for mind==== According to [[Bhikkhu Bodhi]], the post-canonical Pali [[atthakatha|commentary]] uses the three terms ''viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a'', ''[[Manas (early Buddhism)|mano]]'' and ''[[citta]]'' as synonyms for the mind sense base (''mana-[[ayatana]]''); however, in the [[Sutta Pitaka]], these three terms are generally contextualized differently: * '''''Viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''''' refers to awareness through a specific internal sense base, that is, through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body or mind. Thus, there are six sense-specific types of ''Viññā{{IAST|ṇ}}a''. It is also the basis for personal continuity within and across lives. * '''''[[Manas (early Buddhism)|Manas]]''''' refers to mental "actions" (''kamma''), as opposed to those actions that are physical or verbal. It is also the sixth internal sense base (''[[ayatana]]''), that is, the "mind base," cognizing mental sensa (''dhammā'') as well as sensory information from the physical sense bases. * '''''[[Citta]]''''' includes the formation of thought, emotion and volition; this is thus the subject of Buddhist mental development (''[[Buddhist meditation|bhava]]''), the mechanism for release.Bodhi (2000b), pp. 769-70, ''n''. 154. The citta is called "[[Luminous mind|luminous]]" in [[Anguttara Nikaya|A]].I.8-10.Peter Harvey, ''Consciousness Mysticism in the Discourses of the Buddha.'' In Karel Werner, ed., ''The Yogi and the Mystic.'' Curzon Press 1989, page 94. ===Across Buddhist schools=== While most Buddhist schools identify six modes of consciousness, one for each [[ayatana|sense base]], some Buddhist schools have identified additional modes.{{Cite web |url=http://www.chibs.edu.tw/publication/LunCong/023/383-434.htm |title=心識論與唯識說的發展 |access-date=2010-01-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091130085803/http://www.chibs.edu.tw/publication/LunCong/023/383-434.htm |archive-date=2009-11-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ====Six vijñānas==== As described above, in reference to the "All" (''sabba''), the [[Sutta Pitaka]] identifies six vijñānas related to the six sense bases: # Eye consciousness # Ear consciousness # Nose consciousness # Tongue consciousness # Body consciousness # Mind consciousness describe the consciousness of "ideas" - Buddhism describes not five but six perceptions. ====Eight vijñānas==== {{main|Eight Consciousnesses}} The [[Yogacara]] / [[Cittamatra]] school consider two more consciousnesses. # a consciousness called klistamanas, which gathers the hindrances, the poisons, the karmic formations. # the ālāyavijñāna is the consciousness "basis of everything" and has been translated as "store consciousness".Nhat Hanh (2001), pp. 1 ''ff''. Every consciousness is based on this one. It is the phenomenon which explains the [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]]. According to [[Walpola Rahula]], the "store consciousness" of Yogacara thought exists in the early texts as well, as the "citta."Walpola Rahula, quoted in Padmasiri De Silva, Robert Henry Thouless, ''Buddhist and Freudian Psychology.'' Third revised edition published by NUS Press, 1992 page 66, [https://books.google.com/books?id=4Fb0q9bKJjIC&pg=PA65&dq=development+of+the+theory+of+karma+buddhism&lr=#PPA66,M1]. ====Amalavijñāna==== The [[:fr:Amalavijñāna|amalavijñāna]] ([[:ja:阿摩羅識|阿摩羅識]]), "immaculate consciousness", is considered by some Yogācāra schools as a ninth level of consciousness.{{cite book|ref=harv|editor1-last=Buswell|editor1-first=Robert Jr|editor2-last=Lopez|editor2-first=Donald S. Jr.|editor1-link=Robert Buswell Jr.|editor2-link=Donald S. Lopez, Jr.|title=Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism (amalavijñāna)|date=2013|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, NJ|page=33|isbn=9780691157863}} This "pure consciousness is identified with the nature of reality (parinispanna) or Suchness."Paul, Diana (1981). The Structure of Consciousness in Paramārtha's Purported Trilogy, Philosophy East and West, 31/3, 310 Alternatively, amalavijñāna may be considered the pure aspect of ālāyavijñāna. Some buddhists also suggest [[Heart Sutra#Title|hrdaya]] (Heart) consciousnesses (一切一心識), or an eleven consciousnesses theory or an infinity consciousness ([[:zh:无量识|無量識]]).[[:zh:s:佛學大辭典/九識]]{{Cite web |url=http://wiki.fjdh.com/index.php?doc-view-17132.html |title=识-法相词典- 佛教百科 佛教百科 |access-date=2010-01-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711004917/http://wiki.fjdh.com/index.php?doc-view-17132.html |archive-date=2011-07-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ===Contemporary usages=== ''Viññāna'' is used in [[Thai Buddhism]] to refer specifically to one's consciousness or life-force after it has left the body at the moment of death. Thais differentiate between winyaan and "jid-jai" (จิตใจ), which is the consciousness while it is still connected to a living body. Even though the jid-jai leaves the body while you dream at night and can also externalize during advanced meditation practice, it is still connected to the body.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} ==Hinduism== Sri [[Ramakrishna]] defines ''vijñāna'' as :"He alone who, after reaching the Nitya, the Absolute, can dwell in the [[Līlā]], the :Relative, and again climb from the Līlā to the Nitya, has ripe knowledge and :devotion. Sages like [[Narada]] cherished love of God after attaining the Knowledge of :Brahman. This is called vijnāna." Also: "What is vijnana? It is to know God distinctly by realizing His existence through an intuitive experience and to speak to Him intimately."Swami Nikhilananda (1985), ''The Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna'' (Ramakrishna-Vivekananda Center), p. 523 & 1225. Based on ancient texts, V.S.Apte (1890, rev. 1957-59) provides the following definition for ''vijñānam'' (विज्ञानम्): # Knowledge, wisdom, intelligence, understanding; यज्जीव्यते क्षणमपि प्रथितं मनुष्यैर्विज्ञानशौर्यविभवार्यगुणैः समेतम्। तन्नाम जीवितमिह ... [[Panchatantra]] (Pt.) 1.24;5.3; विज्ञानमयः कोशः 'the sheath of intelligence' (the first of the five sheaths of the soul). # Discrimination, discernment. # Skill, proficiency; प्रयोगविज्ञानम् - [[Shringara Tilaka]] (Ś.) 1.2. # Worldly or profane knowledge, knowledge derived from worldly experience (opp. ज्ञान which is 'knowledge of Brahma or Supreme Spirit'); ज्ञानं ते$हं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषत - [[Bhagavad Gita]] (Bg.) 7.2;3.41;6.8; (the whole of the 7th Adhyāya of Bg. explains ज्ञान and विज्ञान). # Business, employment. # Music. # Knowledge of the fourteen lores. # The organ of knowledge; पञ्चविज्ञानचेतने (शरीरे) - [[Mahabharata]] (Mb.) 12.187. 12. # Knowledge beyond the cognisance of the senses (अतीन्द्रियविषय)See Apte (1957-59), p. 1434. Retrieved 1 Feb. 2011 from "U. Chicago" at http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.5:1:2152.apte . In addition, [[Monier Williams]] (1899; rev. 2008) provides the following definition: # to distinguish, discern, observe, investigate, recognize ascertain, know, understand - [[Rig Veda]] (RV.), etc., etc. (with ''na'' and inf.: 'to know not how to'); # to have right knowledge - [[Katha Upanishad]] (KaṭhUp.) # to become wise or learned - Mn. iv, 20; # to hear or learn from (gen.) - [[Chandogya Upanishad]] (ChUp.); [[Mahabharata]] (MBh.); # to recognize in (loc.) - [[Panchatantra]] (Pañcat.); # to look upon or regard or consider as (two acc.), Mn.; MBh., etc.; Kāv., etc.; # to explain, declare - BhP.Monier Williams (1899; rev. 2008), p. 961. Retrieved 1 Feb. 2011 from U.Cologne at http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/monier/serveimg.pl?file=/scans/MWScan/MWScanjpg/mw0961-vijRmbhin.jpg . == See also == * [[Skandha|Aggregates]] * [[Pratitya-samutpada|Dependent Origination]], [[Twelve Nidanas|12 Causes]] * [[Pratītyasamutpāda]] * [[Nibbana#Luminous consciousness|Luminous consciousness]] * [[Rebirth (Buddhism)]] * [[Ayatana|Sense Bases]] * [[Qi]] * [[Prana]] * [[Energy (esotericism)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == * Apte, Viman Shivaram (1957–59). {{DISPLAYTITLE:Wendy Brown (political theorist)}} {{Infobox philosopher | name = Wendy Brown | image=WendyBrown2016.1.jpg | image_size= 220 | caption= Brown in Berkeley, 2016. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|11|28}} | birth_place = | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] | region = [[Western philosophy]] | school_tradition = {{hlist|[[Continental philosophy]] |[[Critical theory]] |[[Third-wave feminism]] |[[Queer theory]] |[[Postmodernism]] |[[Post-structuralism]] |[[Critical legal studies]]}} | main_interests = {{hlist|[[Democracy]] |[[Sovereignty]] |[[Citizenship]] |[[Rights]] |[[Gender]] |[[Identity (social science)|Identity]] |[[Power (social and political)|Power]] |[[Discourse]] |[[Liberalism]] |[[Neoliberalism]] |[[Toleration|Tolerance]] |[[Psychoanalysis]] |[[State (polity)|State]] |[[Law]] |[[Secularism]] |[[Critique]]}} | influences = {{hlist |[[Karl Marx]] |[[Michel Foucault]] |[[Sigmund Freud]] | |[[Friedrich Nietzsche]] |[[Frankfurt School]]| [[Sheldon Wolin]]<!--academic advisor-->}} | influenced = | notable_ideas = }} '''Wendy L. Brown''' (born November 28, 1955) is an American political theorist. She is Class of 1936 First Professor of [[Political Science]] and a core faculty member in The Program for [[Critical Theory]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://polisci.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/person_detail.php?person=225|title=Wendy Brown - People in the Department|website=Polisci.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://townsendlab.berkeley.edu/critical-theory/faculty|title=Faculty - Townsend Humanities Lab|website=Townsendlab.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
==Career== Wendy Brown received her BA in both Economics and Politics from [[UC Santa Cruz]], and her M.A and Ph.D in [[political philosophy]] from [[Princeton University]]. Before she took a position at [[UC Berkeley]] in 1999, Brown taught at [[Williams College]] and [[UC Santa Cruz]]. At Berkeley, beyond her primary teaching roles in Political Theory and Critical Theory, Brown is also an affiliated faculty member of the Department of Rhetoric, the Jurisprudence and Social Policy Program, the Designated Emphasis in Women, Gender and Sexuality, and the Designated Emphasis in Early Modern Studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rhetoric.berkeley.edu/people.php?page_id=1056&c=2|title=UCB Rhetoric - Affiliated Faculty|website=Rhetoric.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
Brown lectures around the world and has held numerous visiting and honorary positions, including at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in Princeton, the [[Institute for Human Sciences]] in Vienna, the [[Goethe University Frankfurt|Goethe University]] in Frankfurt, the [[University of California Humanities Research Institute|UC Humanities Research Institute]] in Irvine, the Institute for the Humanities Critical Theory Summer School at [[Birkbeck, University of London]] (2012, 2015),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbk.ac.uk/bih/events/london-critical-theory-summer-school|title=London Critical Theory Summer School — The Birkbeck Institute for the Humanities, Birkbeck, University of London|website=Bbk.ac.uk|language=en-us|access-date=2017-07-19}}</ref> a Senior Invited Fellow of the Center for Humanities at [[Cornell University]] (2013), a Visiting Professor at [[Columbia University]] (2014), a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] Visiting Lecturer (2014),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbk.org/WEB/PBK_Member/PROGRAMS/Visiting_Scholars/2014-2015/Wendy_Brown.aspx|title=Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Lectures|website=Pbk.org|accessdate=2016-02-04}}</ref> a Visiting Professor of Law and Government at [[Cornell University]] (2015), the Shimizu Visiting Professor of Law at the [[London School of Economics]] (2015),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/genderInstitute/whosWho/profiles/visitingAcademics/pastVisitors.aspx |title=Previous Visitors to the Gender Institute at the LSE|website=Lse.ac.uk |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> and a Visiting Professor at the [[European Graduate School]] (2016).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://egs.edu/faculty/wendy-brown/lectures|title=Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
Among the honorary lectures Brown has delivered are the Beaverbrook Annual Lecture at McGill University (2015);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcgill.ca/ahcs/channels/event/2015-beaverbrook-annual-lecture-wendy-brown-neoliberalism-contra-democracy-ten-theses-255258|title=2015 Beaverbrook Annual Lecture{{!}} Wendy Brown {{!}} "Neoliberalism Contra Democracy: Ten Theses"|website=Art History & Communication Studies|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> the Pembroke Center keynote at Brown University (2015);<ref>{{Citation|last=Brown University|title=Feminist Change and the University: Keynote Address by Wendy Brown (Video 3 of 3)|date=2015-03-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D2Eop1_T02s|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> a keynote at the Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility (2016);<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://zolberginstitute.org/zimm-launch-event-mobility-in-post-democracy-with-keynote-address-by-wendy-brown-october-20th-6-30pm-the-auditorium-66-west-12th-street/|title=ZIMM launch event: "Mobility in Post-Democracy" keynote lecture by Wendy Brown, October 20th 6.30pm, The Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. {{!}} Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility|date=2016-10-05|work=Zolberg Institute on Migration and Mobility|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref> the fourth "Democracy Lecture" – following [[Thomas Piketty]], [[Naomi Klein]], and [[Paul Mason (journalist)|Paul Mason]] – in the Haus der Kulturen der Welt in Berlin (2017);<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hkw.de/de/programm/projekte/2015/democracy_lectures/democracy_lectures_start.php|title=Democracy Lectures|last=|first=|date=|website=Haus der Kulturen der Welt|language=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-29}}</ref> a plenary speech at the European Sociological Association conference in Athens (2017);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esa13thconference.eu/|title=13th ESA Conference {{!}} Athens {{!}} 29.08 - 01.09.2017|website=13th Conference of the European Sociological Association|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref> the Wellek Lectures at UC Irvine (2018);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanities.uci.edu/critical/events/past_wellek.php|title=Wellek Lecture Series {{!}} UCI Critical Theory|website=www.humanities.uci.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> and the Gauss Lecture at Princeton University (2018).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://humanities.princeton.edu/event/gauss-seminar-in-criticism/|title=Gauss Seminar in Criticism: Wendy Brown|work=Humanities Council|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en}}</ref>
Brown's work has been translated into more than twenty languages and has received many awards. Brown served as Council Member of the [[American Political Science Association]] (2007–09) and as Chair of the UC Humanities Research Institute Board of Governors (2009–11).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uchri.org/profiles/wendy-brown-3|title=Wendy Brown - UC Humanities Research InstituteUC Humanities Research Institute|website=Uchri.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref> In 2012, her book Walled States, Waning Sovereignty won the David Eastman Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsanet.org/MEMBERSHIP/Organized-Sections-by-Title/Organized-Section-Awards/Section-17 |title=David Eastman Award from the Foundations of Political Thought Section of the American Political Science Association|website=Apsanet.org|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> Brown received the 2016 Distinguished Teaching Award, UC Berkeley's most prestigious honor for teaching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teaching.berkeley.edu/programs/distinguished-teaching-award/2016-distinguished-teaching-award-recipients|title=UC Berkeley Distinguished Teaching Award to Wendy Brown|website=Teaching.berkeley.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> She received a UC Presidents Humanities Research Fellowship (2017–18) and is currently a [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Fellow]] (2017–18).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.berkeley.edu/2017/04/07/guggenheim-fellows-2017|title=Gugenheim Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=News.berkeley.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/wendy-brown|title=Current Guggenheim Fellow Wendy Brown|website=Gf.org|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
Brown's thinking on the decline of sovereignty and the hollowing out of democracy has found popular and journalistic audiences, with discussions of her arguments appearing in ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]''{{'}} articles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jul/31/democracy-dying-people-worried-putin-erdogan-trump-world|title=Democracy is dying – and it's startling how few people are worried|last=Mason|first=Paul|date=2017-07-31|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-08-03|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/06/opinion/sunday/the-walls-in-our-heads.html|title=The Walls in Our Heads|last=Vanderbilt|first=Tom|date=2016-11-04|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Brown has appeared in documentary films including "The Value of the Humanities" (2014) and "What is Democracy?" (directed by [[Astra Taylor]], 2017).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thevalueofthehumanities.com/|title=The Value of the Humanities|last=ValueMedia|website=www.thevalueofthehumanities.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2017/05/29/what-is-democracy-astra-taylors-necessary-new-doc/|title=What is Democracy? Astra Taylor's Necessary New Doc - NFB/blog|date=2017-05-29|work=NFB/blog|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
Together with [[Michel Feher]], Brown is co-editor of the Zone Books' series '''''Near Futures''''' and its digital supplement '''''Near Futures Online'''''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/pdf/ZoneBooks2015.pdf|title=Near Futures, Series Announcement|publisher=Zone Books|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/category/series/zone-near-futures|title=Near Futures, publications from Zone Books and MIT Press|website=Mitpress.mit.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} {{cite web|url=http://www.nearfuturesonline.org|title=Near Futures Online Issue No. 1 (March 2016) “Europe at a Crossroads”|website=Nearfuturesonline.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Overview of work== Brown has established new paradigms in [[critical legal studies]] and [[feminist theory]].<ref>Wendy Brown, Christina Colegate, John Dalton, Timothy Rayner, Cate Thill, [http://sydney.edu.au/contretemps/6January2006/brown.pdf Learning to Love Again: An Interview with Wendy Brown], Contretemps 6, January 2006: 25-42</ref> She has produced a body of work drawing from [[Marx]]'s critique of capitalism and its relation to religion and secularism,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quiparle.dukejournals.org/content/23/1.toc|title="Is Marx (Capital) Secular?" Qui Parle (2014) 23(1): 109-124.|last=Brown|first=Wendy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.freie-radios.net/41387 |title=FRN: Is Marx (Capital) Secular? Vortrag von Wendy Brown vom Re-thinking Marx Kongress |website=Freie-radios.net |date= |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref> [[Nietzsche]]'s usefulness for thinking about power and the ruses of morality, [[Max Weber]] on the modern organization of power, [[Freudian psychoanalysis]] and its implications for political identification,<ref>R Gressgård. [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/08038740802441063 "Feminist Theorizes the Political: The Political Theory of Wendy Brown"], tandfonline.com; accessed February 1, 2017.</ref> [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]]'s work on governmentality and [[neoliberalism]], as well as other contemporary [[Continental philosophy|continental philosophers]].<ref name="springer1">{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|title=Feminism, Law, and Neoliberalism: An Interview and Discussion with Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 6, 2017 | doi=10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|volume=24|journal=Feminist Legal Studies|pages=69–89 | last1 = Cruz | first1 = Katie}}</ref><ref name="sociologicalimagination.org">{{cite web|url=http://sociologicalimagination.org/archives/17800|title=Author Meets Readers: Wendy Brown's Undoing the Demos|website=Sociologicalimagination.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Bringing these resources together with her own thinking on a range of topics, Brown's work aims to diagnose modern and contemporary formations of [[political power]], and to discern the threats to democracy entailed by such formations.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z |title=Feminism, Law, and Neoliberalism: An Interview and Discussion with Wendy Brown|accessdate=June 6, 2017 | doi=10.1007/s10691-016-9314-z|volume=24|journal=Feminist Legal Studies|pages=69–89 | last1 = Cruz | first1 = Katie}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sociologicalimagination.org/archives/17800 |title=Author Meets Readers: Wendy Brown's Undoing the Demos|website=Sociologicalimagination.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
===''States of Injury: Power and Freedom in Late Modernity'' (1995)=== In this work Brown asks how a sense of woundedness can become the basis for individual and collective forms of identity. From outlawing hate speech to banning pornography, Brown argues, well-intentioned attempts at protection can legitimize the state while harming subjects by codifying their identities as helpless or in need of continuous governmental regulation. While breaking ground in political theory, this work also represents one of Brown's key interventions in feminist and queer theory. The book offers a novel account of legal and political power as constitutive of norms of sexuality and gender. Through the concept of "wounded attachments", Brown contends that psychic injury may accompany and sustain racial, ethnic, and gender categories, particularly in relation to state law and discursive formations. In this and other works Brown has criticized representatives of second wave feminism, such as [[Catharine MacKinnon]], for reinscribing the category of "woman" as an essentialized identity premised on injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acc.english.ucsb.edu/ACGCC%2014-15/Brown_The%20Impossibility%20of%20Women%27s%20Studies.pdf|title=The Impossibility of Women's Studies|website=acc.english.ucsb.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/5715.html|title=States of Injury book description|website=Press.princeton.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} Prior to ''States of Injury'', Brown addressed ''Toward a Feminist Theory of the State'' (1989) in ''[[The Nation]]'', characterizing it as a "profoundly static world view and undemocratic, perhaps even anti-democratic, political sensibility" as well as "flatly dated" and "developed at 'the dawn of feminism's second wave ... framed by a political-intellectual context that no longer exists -- a male Marxist monopoly on radical social discourse'". See Wendy Brown, "Consciousness Razing", ''[[The Nation]]'', January 8/15, 1990, pp. 61–64. for reinscribing the category of "woman" as an essentialized identity premised on injury.</ref>
=== ''Politics Out of History'' (2001) === This book comprises a series of essays on contemporary political issues from the problem of moralism in politics to the legacies of past injustices in the present. Throughout her thematically overlapping chapters, Brown asks: "What happens to left and liberal political orientations when faith in progress is broken, when both the sovereign individual and sovereign states seem tenuous, when desire seems as likely to seek punishment as freedom, when all political conviction is revealed as contingent and subjective?"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://press.princeton.edu/titles/7210.html|title=Politics Out of History|website=Princeton University Press|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> Much of this book takes history and liberalism themselves as objects of theoretical reflection and sites of contestation. Drawing on a range of thinkers, such as [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]], [[Karl Marx|Marx]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]], [[Baruch Spinoza|Spinoza]], [[Walter Benjamin|Benjamin]] and [[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]], Brown rethinks the disorientation and possibility inherent to contemporary democracy.
===''Edgework: Critical Essays on Knowledge and Politics'' (2005)=== This work consists of seven articles responding to particular occasions, each of which "mimic, in certain ways, the experience of the political realm: one is challenged to think here, now, about a problem that is set and framed by someone else, and to do so before a particular audience or in dialogue with others not of one's own choosing." Each individual essay begins with a specific problem: what is the relationship between love, loyalty, and dissent in contemporary American political life?; how did neoliberal rationality become a form of governmentality?; what are the main problems of women's studies programs?; and so on. According to Brown, the essays do not aim to definitively answer the given questions but "to critically interrogate the framing and naming practices, challenge the dogmas (including those of the Left and of feminism), and discern the constitutive powers shaping the problem at hand."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8079.html|title=Wendy Brown, Edgework, Princeton University Press|website=Press.princeton.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
===''Regulating Aversion: Tolerance in the Age of Identity and Empire'' (2006)=== In this book, Brown subverts the usual and widely accepted notion that [[Toleration|tolerance]] is one of the most remarkable achievements of Western modernity. She suggests that tolerance (or toleration) cannot be perceived as the complete opposite to violence. At times, it can also be used to justify violence. Brown argues that tolerance primarily operates as a discourse of subject construction and a mode of governmentality that addresses or confirms asymmetric relations between different groups, each of which must then "tolerate" other groups and categories or "be tolerated" by the dominant groups and categories.
To substantiate her thesis, Brown examines the tolerance discourse of figures like [[George W. Bush]], [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Samuel P. Huntington|Samuel Huntington]], [[Susan Okin]], [[Michael Ignatieff]], [[Bernard Lewis]], and [[Seyla Benhabib]] and argues that "tolerance as a political practice is always conferred by the dominant, it is always a certain expression of domination even as it offers protection or incorporation to the less powerful."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8306.html|title=Regulating Aversion|website=Princeton University Press|access-date=2017-07-23}}</ref> Among those influenced by Brown's thinking on this subject are [[Joan Wallach Scott]] and [[Slavoj Žižek]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Žižek|first=Slavoj|date=2008-04-01|title=Tolerance as an Ideological Category|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/592539|journal=Critical Inquiry|volume=34|issue=4|pages=660–682|doi=10.1086/592539|issn=0093-1896}}</ref> whose respective works ''The Politics of the Veil'' (2007) and ''Violence: Six Sideways Reflections'' (2007) draw heavily on Brown's account of tolerance discourse.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YD74-yqAp-cC&pg=PR11&lpg=PR11&dq=joan+wallach+scott+politics+of+the+veil+wendy+brown&source=bl&ots=Gw58u1KuHR&sig=Llvq6iqdC19pO2Sls2_RMFnR8mE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1vMiMraDVAhWCxFQKHUP3A08Q6AEIVzAH#v=onepage&q=joan%20wallach%20scott%20politics%20of%20the%20veil%20wendy%20brown&f=false |title=The Politics of the Veil |author=Joan Wallach Scott |page=11 |website=Books.google.com |date=2010-08-22 |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?bav=on.2,or.r_cp.&biw=1118&bih=618&um=1&ie=UTF-8&lr&cites=7277941321159015026 |title=Google Scholar |website=Scholar.google.com |date=2001-09-11 |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref>
In a debate with [[Rainer Forst]] at the ICI in Berlin Brown addressed this problematic again,<ref>[https://www.ici-berlin.org/videos/spannungsuebung-3/ The power of tolerance]'' – Debate between Wendy Brown and Rainer Forst, ICI Berlin, 2008] (July 16, 2015).</ref> later published as a co-authored book, The Power of Tolerance (2014). Here Brown argues against primarily moral or normative approaches to power and discourse, and warns against the dangers of uncritically celebrating the liberal ideal of tolerance, as frequently happens in Western notions of historical, civilizational or moral progress.<ref>[http://cup.columbia.edu/book/the-power-of-tolerance/9780231170185 ''The Power of Tolerance: A Debate''], Columbia.edu (July 16, 2015).</ref>
===''Les Habits neufs de la politique mondiale'' (2007)=== Published exclusively in French, ''Les habits neufs de la politique mondiale'' (''The New Clothes of World Politics'') argues that the following political fact is irreversible: liberal democracy, as a global social and historical modality of statecraft, is dying. The two movements delivering such blows, neoliberalism and neoconservatism, feature both resonances and disonances. Brown argues that whilst the former acts as a political rationality, a mode of general regulation of behavior, the latter is both necessary to its survival, and parasitic of its survival. As a form of governmentality that redefines freedom, neoliberalism will moralize politics, limiting its scope; this is the function of neo-conservatism.
===''Walled States, Waning Sovereignty'' (2010)=== This book examines the revival of wall-building under shifting conditions of global capitalism. Brown not only problematizes the assumed functions of walls, such as the prevention of crime, migration, smuggling, and so on. She also argues that walling has taken on new a significance due to its symbolic function in an increasingly globalized and precarious world of financial capital. As individual identity as well as nation-state sovereignty are threatened, walls become objects invested with individual and collective desire. Anxious efforts to shore up national identity are thus projected onto borders as well as new material structures that would appear to secure them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/titles/BROW_WAL.html |title=Zone Books, Wendy Brown's Walled States, Waning Sovereignty|website=Zonebooks.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}} See also, Timothy Shenk, "[https://www.dissentmagazine.org/blog/booked-3-what-exactly-is-neoliberalism-wendy-brown-undoing-the-demos Booked #3: What Exactly Is Neoliberalism?]" Dissent Magazine</ref> The book was reprinted with a new preface by the author following the 2016 election of [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zonebooks.org/pdf/ZoneBooks2017.pdf |format=PDF |title=Zone Books |date=2017 |website=Zonebooks.org |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref>
===''Undoing the Demos: Neoliberalism's Stealth Revolution'' (2015)=== Brown's study begins by engaging and revising key arguments in [[Michel Foucault]]'s ''The Birth of Biopolitics'' with the aim of analyzing different ways that democracy is being hollowed out by neoliberal rationality.<ref name="sociologicalimagination.org"/> She describes neoliberalism as a thoroughgoing attack on the most foundational ideas and practices of democracy. The individual chapters of the book examine the effects of neoliberalization on higher education, law,<ref name="springer1"/> governance,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicseminar.org/2015/08/on-wendy-brown/#.WTZ0JBN97wc|title=On Wendy Brown|website=Publicseminar.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> the basic principles of liberal democratic institutions,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/european-journal-of-sociology-archives-europeennes-de-sociologie/article/undoing-the-undoing-of-the-demos-brown-wendy-undoing-the-demos-neoliberalisms-stealth-revolution-new-york-zone-books-2015/A50DF30DA9958B43CA3A795F7EEB0B66|title=Review of Wendy Brown: Undoing the Demos|website=Cambridge.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> as well as radical democratic imaginaries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/column/194010-neoliberalism-is-changing-our-world-without-our-even-noticing|title=Undoing the Demos Review in Pop Matters|website=Popmatters.com|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
Brown treats "neoliberalism as a governing rationality through which everything is 'economized' and in a very specific way: human beings become market actors and nothing but, every field of activity is seen as a market, and every entity (whether public or private, whether person, business, or state) is governed as a firm." To address such threats, Brown argues, democracy must be reinvigorated not only as an object of theoretical inquiry but also as a site of political struggle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zonebooks.org/titles/BROW_UND.html |title=Zone Books, Wendy Brown: Undoing the Demos |website=Zonebooks.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
=== ''Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom, White Nationalism, and the Weaponization of Moral Values'' === Brown is currently researching right nationalism in the US, completing a book provisionally titled ''Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom, White Nationalism, and the Weaponization of Moral Values''. The book will shift between the frames of neoliberal governmentality, Nietzsche's social analysis and Marcuse's psychoanalysis to explain the production of a society unmoored from moral concerns (hence social justice), obligations to truth (the post-truth moment) and democratic interests (replaced by the self-interest of human capital). Brown draws from [[The Will to Power (manuscript)|The Will to Power]] by Nietzsche and Marcuse's [[One-Dimensional Man]], attributing these right energies to a combination of world-historical nihilism and forces of consumer culture in advance industrial society. Nihilism has, Brown argues, largely generated 'neoliberal reason itself, which posits no value apart from that generated by price and speculative markets.'<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Wendy|date=2018|title=Neoliberalism's Frankenstein: Authoritarian Freedom in Twenty-First Century "Democracies"|url=https://ctjournal.org/index.php/criticaltimes/article/view/12|journal=Critical Times: Interventions in Global Critical Theory|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|page=71|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Public life == [[File:Wendy Brown delivering the Democracy Lecture at the HKW Berlin in 2017. Photograph by Santiago Engelhardt.jpg|thumb|Wendy Brown giving the Democracy Lecture at the HKW Berlin in 2017. Photo by Santiago Engelhardt.]] A prominent public intellectual in the United States, Brown has written and spoken about issues of free speech,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2014/10/free-speech-is-not-for-feeling-safe-by-wendy-brown/|title=Free Speech is not for Feeling Safe, by Wendy Brown|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> public education, political protest,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2014/09/the-operation-of-the-machine/|title=Event on the Operation of the Machine|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> LGBTQ issues, sexual assault,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2016/03/statement-on-sexual-harassment-at-uc-berkeley|title=Feminist Statement on Sexual Harassment at UC Berkeley|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Donald Trump,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://criticaltheory.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Brown.The-End-of-the-World-as-We-Know-It.Artforum.December-2016.pdf|title=The End of the World as We Know It|last=Brown|first=Wendy|date=|website=Criticaltheory.berkeley.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> conservatism, neoliberalism,<ref>{{Citation|last=New Economic Thinking|title=Wendy Brown: How Neoliberalism Threatens Democracy|date=2016-05-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZMMJ9HqzRcE|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=2017-07-25}}</ref> and other matters of national and international concern.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nearfuturesonline.org|title=Near Futures Online Issue No. 1 (March 2016) “Europe at a Crossroads” (Wendy Brown, consulting editor)|website=Nearfuturesonline.org|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
For decades, Brown has been active in efforts to resist measures toward the privatization of the [[University of California]] system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21528635|title=The Economist|website=Economist.com|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref> In her capacity as co-chair of the Berkeley Faculty Association, she raised awareness, organized marches, and spoke publicly about the privatization of public education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2011/09/talking-points-in-defense-of-uc-and-public-education|title=In Defense of UC and Public Education|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> She has been critical of the university's decision to cut costs by utilizing lecturers rather than hiring tenure and tenure track professors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/07/07/academic-council-approves-recommendation-to-utilize-more-lecturers|title=The Daily Californian - Academic Council approves recommendation to utilize more lecturers|website=Dailycal.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> Relatedly, she has voiced concern over the perils of the UC's proposed online education programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2010/10/wendy-brown-on-online-education|title=Wendy Brown on Online Education|date=2010-10-20|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref><ref>For Brown's article on this topic, published in a "Qui Parle" special issue, see {{cite web|url=https://www.dukeupress.edu/qui-parle-20-1/?viewby=title|title=Wendy Brown article on Education in Qui Parle: Critical Humanities and Social Sciences|website=Dukeupress.edu|date=2010-10-20|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref>
Brown has criticized university administration for their response to sexual assault. "I think many faculty feel there are repeat harassers on our faculty who are never charged ... Graduate students gave up on careers, and these perpetrators were allowed to continue, and that was wrong—never should have happened," she said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2016/03/28/feminist-uc-berkeley-faculty-members-call-for-improved-response-to-sex-harassment|title=Feminist UC Berkeley faculty members call for improved sexual harassment policy|website=Dailycal.org |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
At the "99 Mile March" to Sacramento she addressed her criticism to more general trends: "We are marching to draw attention to the plight of public education in California and to implore Californians to re-invest in it. For all its resources, innovation and wealth, California has sunk to nearly the bottom of the nation in per student spending, and our public higher education system, once the envy of the world, is in real peril."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucbfa.org/2012/02/uc-faculty-join-99-mile-march-to-sacramento|title=UC Faculty Join "99 Mile March" to Sacramento|website=Ucbfa.org|accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> Brown supported [[Occupy Wall Street]] as part of the UC faculty council,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/10/16/uc-faculty-council-endorses-occupy-wall-street|title=UC faculty council endorses Occupy Wall Street | The Daily Californian|date=2011-10-16|website=Dailycal.org|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref> claiming that "We understand this to be part of what (the movement) stands for. We are delighted by the protests and consider our campaign to be at one with it."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/384018/summary|title=On the Demos, by Wendy Brown|website=Muse.jhu.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/459205|title=On Occupy|website=Muse.jhu.edu|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Brown is a native of [[California]] and lives in Berkeley with her wife [[Judith Butler]] and son.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/06/judith-butler-c-v-r.html|title=It's Judith Butler's World - The Cut|website=Nymag.com|accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref>

[[Image:Yakzan pic.jpg|left|150px]]'''Yakzan Hugo Valdez''' (Hugo Salvador Valdez, Oct 20, 1937 - May 24, 1993) was a Sheikh of the [[Sufi Order International]] initiated by [[Pir Vilayat Inayat Khan]] and of the [[Mevlevi Order]] initiated by [http://sufism.org/lineage/mevlevi/the-voice-of-a-dede Suleyman Hayati Dede], Sheikh of Konya. Yakzan was additionally a celebrated master of the [[Dances of Universal Peace]] as originated by [[Samuel L. Lewis]] and an acknowledged peer of the Sheikhs of the [http://www.ruhaniat.org/ Sufi Islamia Ruhaniat Society]. Yakzan was a long term resident of Honolulu, Hawaii. He established Sufi communities in Hawaii, Chile, and Spain.
Yakzan was born in Jujuy, Argentina, and was tutored as a child under the educational curriculum of [[Rudolf Steiner]]. He moved to New York City as a young man where he studied design and [[Ikebana]]. Enamored with the teachings of [[Pir (Sufism)|Pir]]-O-[[Murshid]] [[Inayat Khan]] as taught by his son, [[Pir Vilayat Inayat Khan]], Yakzan received multiple initiations culminating in initiation as Sheikh of the Sufi Order. Yakzan created a series of trainings or “intensives” that distilled the teachings of [[Oscar Ichazo]] of the [[Arica School]] and the principles of [[Gurdjieff]]’s [[Fourth Way]] in combination with the tenets of [[Sufism]] as derived from the work of [[Ibn 'Arabi]], [[Pir (Sufism)|Pir]]-O-[[Murshid]] [[Inayat Khan]], [[Pir Vilayat Inayat Khan]], and [[Murshid]] [[Samuel L. Lewis]].
Yakzan was a charismatic teacher of [[Sufism]], the [http://etext.virginia.edu/journals/ssr/issues/volume3/number2/ssr03-02-e04.html Path of Love]. A number of renowned teachers and spiritual masters visited and taught in Hawaii as guests of Yakzan and the Sufi Order of Honolulu. Among their number were [[Pir Vilayat Inayat Khan]], [[Reshad Feild]], [http://www.gurdjieffdominican.com/Pierre_Elliot_biography.html Pierre Elliot] of [[Gurdjieff]]’s [[Fourth Way]] and his son Hugh Elliot, [http://www.superluminal.com/cookbook/gallery_suleyman_dede.html Suleyman Hayati Dede], Sheikh of Konya and his son [http://www.gurdjieffdominican.com/Jelaluddin_Interview.html Jelaluddin Loras], [http://remembrance.sufipaths.net/?page_id=517 Sheikh Vasheest Davenport], [http://www.churchofall.us/t1.html Shaykha Tasnim Hermila Fernandez], and [http://www.zuleikha.com/ Zuleikha].
